text:
As someone who's often been on the other end of test assignments, I'd also recommend offering to pay a candidate to do the test. Doing one takes time & effort, so it makes good sense to compensate them for that.

It doesn't have to be a big amount, but at least offer it up-front. It shows that you're serious about hiring someone, that you value the work they're putting into it, and it alleviates the candidate's stress about giving you "free" work or ideas.

(And, hi Keri! :wave: )

text: With in-house writers who are in a broader “content specialist” role, how do you strike the balance between providing a thorough brief vs. encouraging them to explore angles and make a piece their own? Right now I try to provide very thorough briefs, but there are times when I want to throw it out the window and just say, “you know the topic, you have keywords, otherwise run with it and decide what direction you want this to go!” However, I suspect there’s a happy middle ground and would love to hear thoughts from you all!

text: So curious what people do here. I've done both "thorough brief" and had trained writers to do their own optimization. In the latter case, each writer would do research around the primary keyword and put together a detailed outline + their thoughts about the searcher intent, and then I'd review before drafting.

text: i think you have to balance less instruction with more training/resources. the writer has to really understand the audience, the topic, and the goals / the WHY behind the content and the underlying strategy before they can take a topic/keyword and run with it. otherwise they'll take it in the wrong direction and you won't get the results you need.

text: The detail of my briefs depend on the seniority of the writer and whether or not I have a very clear idea of what I think a piece of content should look like vs. just a more high-level goal of what that content should achieve. Generally, my goal has always been to train my writers to ideate and optimize on their own. But I make sure to provide a framework for them to work with, to ensure that they ask the right questions and follow best practices when planning their content. I put together a detailed content planning template that writers need to fill out before diving into the writing that gets them to specify things like target audience, primary and supporting keywords, high-level format of the content, competitor research for the SERP, visual assets etc. I also put together a content optimization checklist that writers have to go through once their draft is complete, and once their content is finalized and ready for publication.

text:
Some general observations from chatting with 100+ teams on how they build briefs:

We mostly see our customers leaning towards heavier briefs for newer writers, outside writers, and content where matching search intent and ranking factors is critical.

As the project becomes less SEO critical and more driven by thought leadership types of factors or expertise, we usually recommend fewer brief requirements and more specific brand/audience requirements.

In regards to training - in-house teams lean more towards writers building their own briefs than most of the agencies we talk to, and  when you get to the point of training writers to review the search results and understand how to rank, the brief can be flipped around so that writers build them and get them reviewed/approved by strategists before proceeding with full article, rather than the other way around.

text: Only other thing that I don’t think I saw mentioned above is: the writer should be aware of the analytics/reception of the post. it might take a while for pure seo long tail, but I’m okay with some folks developing their own stuff. However, we will review how it performed on owned channels. I always want to be conscious of promoting creativity & not being a roadblock for new ideas, but it’s about the customer and what they consume/interact with.

text: Expanding on thought leadership — be cognizant that most of the tools you’re using for brief research are based on what’s already out there. If you’re trying to say something new, or unique, that’s when it pays to invest less time in brief building and give the writer more freedom — especially if they already know the topic.

text: Personally I haven’t found a test that can replicate the actual process of taking a piece from brief to completion. So if we’re starting a larger project we might pick 3-4 writers, give them 1-2 assignments to start — paid, of course — and see how it goes. Freelancers live complicated lives, so of those 3-4 one will usually drop off the map completely, another will be hard to work with for one reason or another, but out of that group we can usually find the people or person we need.
